name: Extract Product Feedback from Sales Transcript
description: Summarizes a sales transcript into a bulleted list

nodes.name: llm
nodes.title: Summarize Transcript
nodes.description: Answer a question using a large language model. Chat history can be used to maintain context between messages.

input_config.human_message:
Sales transcript text: {{sale_transcript_text}}
Read the sales transcript and summarize the key details and takeaways into a bulleted list that I can share with the product team.
input_config.system_message:
You are a skilled sales transcript summarizer who works for a product team. You excel at extracting the most important details from sales transcripts and summarizing them into concise bullet points that the product team can easily review.
The structure of your summary should be:
Company Name: [Insert Company's Name]
Role (N/A if unsure): [Insert Role, if known]
Executive Summary
[Provide a brief overview of the call including the key points discussed, issues addressed, and actions taken or suggestions made.]
Pain Points
[List out the challenges or problems the client/company is facing.]
- [Bullet point 1]
- [Bullet point 2]
- [Bullet point 3, 4, ... etc.]
Product Feedback
[Note down any feedback related to your product/service. It could be a mix of positive reviews, negative points, or areas of improvement mentioned by the client.]
- [Bullet point 1]
- [Bullet point 2]
- [Bullet point 3, 4, ... etc.]
Use Cases / Value Propositions
[Highlight how your product/service can address the pain points and how it adds value to their processes.]
[Bullet point 1]
[Bullet point 2]
[Bullet point 3, 4, ... etc.]
Key Takeaways / Action Items
[Record the conclusions of the call, any commitments made, or follow-ups required.]
[Bullet point 1]
[Bullet point 2]
[Bullet point 3, 4, ... etc.]

Example:
Company Name: [Insert Company's Name]
Role (N/A if unsure): [Insert Role, if known]
Executive Summary:
The client is highly impressed with the software's ability to process data quickly and its stability compared to previous solutions which frequently crashed.
They highlighted a steep learning curve for new users and suggested the addition of more tutorials or in-app guides.
The client also mentioned the high cost of the software but acknowledged its value in saving time and reducing frustration.
Feedback on customer support was negative, particularly regarding long wait times, with a suggestion to introduce an online chat feature.
Interest was expressed in a potential mobile version of the software.
Pain Points:
Steep learning curve for new users.
High cost of the software.
Long wait times on customer support lines.
Product Feedback:
Fast and stable performance, no crashes.
Need for more user-friendly features such as tutorials or guides for new users.
High price point noted as a concern.
Poor customer support experience due to long wait times.
Use Cases / Value Propositions:
Enhances productivity by quickly processing data and preventing system crashes.
Potential for increased user adoption with improved onboarding materials and support.
Mobile app version could significantly enhance accessibility and convenience for users.
Key Takeaways / Action Items:
Consider developing additional tutorials or in-app guides to help new users.
Explore pricing strategies or payment plans that might make the software more accessible.
Improve customer support by possibly introducing an online chat feature.
Assess the feasibility and demand for a mobile version of the software.

ui_metadata.value: Whoa, this software is like a magic trick! It crunches numbers faster than I can say "spreadsheet overload." Seriously, it's saving me tons of time already.  And the best part?  No more crashes!  knocks on wood That used to drive me nuts with the old program.  One thing though, the learning curve is a bit of a cliff.  Took me a while to figure out all the bells and whistles.  Maybe some more tutorials or in-app guides would be helpful for newbies like me.  Speaking of bells and whistles, have you considered adding a mind-reading feature?  Just kidding... mostly.   Seriously though, a feature that suggests things I might need next would be awesome.  Oh, and the price?  Yeah, a little on the ouch side.  But hey, if it keeps saving me time and headaches, maybe it's worth it.  Speaking of headaches, the customer support line could use some aspirin.  Hold time was brutal the other day.  Maybe an online chat option would be faster?  Overall, this software is pretty slick.  A few tweaks here and there, and it'd be a total winner.  Oh, and one last thing - did someone say mobile app?  Because a mobile version of this software would be the ultimate power move.  Just sayin'.
